contentrichtext.text: {{Location map |New Zealand | width = | float = right | caption = Wakefield, New Zealand | alt = | label = Wakefield | position = left | lat =-41.4 | long = 173.05 }} The small New Zealand community of '''Wakefield''' is situated some 25 km south west of [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]] at the top of the [[South Island]]. First settled in about 1843, it was originally called Pitfure. However the name was soon changed to Wakefield. This name was after the town of [[Wakefield]] in [[Yorkshire]], and not, as many assume, after Captain [[Arthur Wakefield]] who led the expedition that first established Nelson City and Province. [[File:Wakefield Anglican Church.JPG|thumb|left|St John's Church]] Wakefield is notable for Wakefield Primary School, the oldest school in continuous usage in New Zealand. It was set up in 1843 by Mary Ann Baigent, the wife of [[Edward Baigent]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Our School|url=http://www.wakefield.school.nz/our-school/|publisher=Wakefield School|accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> St John's Church in 120 Edward Street, built in 1864, is New Zealand's second oldest surviving church. It is registered by the [[New Zealand Historic Places Trust]] as a Category I heritage structure, with registration number 40.<ref>{{NZHPT|40|St John's Church (Anglican)|11 May 2012}}</ref> Wakefield comes under the responsibility of the [[Tasman District]] Council, which has its offices in the nearby town of [[Richmond, New Zealand|Richmond]]. It is part of the West-Coast Tasman General Electorate. There is a small [[newspaper|paper]] called the Wakefield Village News published monthly and distributed to the community. ==References== {{commons category|Wakefield, New Zealand}} {{more footnotes|date=March 2010}} {{Reflist}} *McAloon, J.
